title: How to Get Ink Stains Out of Jeans

steps.title: Dab the stain with a paper towel to soak up excess ink.
steps.content: Dab the stain with a paper towel to soak up excess ink. It’s important to do this right away, while the ink is still wet. Don’t rub or wipe the area—this pushes the ink deeper into the fabric and causes it to spread, which makes it harder to remove. Simply press the paper towel gently into the stain and continue to blot until you've removed as much of the ink as possible. [1] X Research source Check the care label on your jeans before moving onto the next step. If the label says “dry clean only,” pause here and take your jeans to the dry cleaners to remove the stain. If it says your jeans are machine washable, move on to the next step.

steps.title: Place a clean wash cloth inside the jeans under the stain.
steps.content: Place a clean wash cloth inside the jeans under the stain. This prevents the ink from transferring to other parts of the fabric during the stain removal process. [2] X Research source If you don’t have a towel or a wash cloth, a few paper towels should do the trick.

steps.title: Apply a small amount of rubbing alcohol to the stain.
steps.content: Apply a small amount of rubbing alcohol to the stain. For a larger stain, slowly and carefully pour a few drops of 90% isopropyl alcohol directly to the area. For a smaller stain, wet a cotton ball or cotton swab with the alcohol and apply it to the stain. [3] X Expert Source Susan Stocker Stain Removal Specialist Expert Interview. 8 November 2019. Make sure you’re only getting the alcohol on the stained area, so the ink doesn’t bleed or spread. If you’re worried about how the alcohol will affect the fabric, do a patch test on a small, unnoticeable area first.

steps.title: Blot the stain with a clean cloth, paper towel, or cotton ball.
steps.content: Blot the stain with a clean cloth, paper towel, or cotton ball. As you dab, the ink should be drawn out of the fabric. [4] X Expert Source Susan Stocker Stain Removal Specialist Expert Interview. 8 November 2019. When your towel or cotton ball starts to get stained, discard it and use a fresh one to continue dabbing at the area. Continue this process until you’ve soaked up as much of the ink as possible. For older, more severe stains, allow the alcohol to sit for about 15 minutes before blotting.

steps.title: Rinse the area with water to remove the alcohol.
steps.content: Rinse the area with water to remove the alcohol. Be sure to use cold water, as hot water may set any remaining ink into the fabric, making it much harder to remove. [5] X Expert Source Susan Stocker Stain Removal Specialist Expert Interview. 8 November 2019.

steps.title: Wash the jeans in the washing machine as you normally would.
steps.content: Wash the jeans in the washing machine as you normally would. Wash the jeans on their own if possible, so that no leftover ink transfers to other garments during the washing process. Make sure to follow any special instructions on the care label of your jeans regarding water temperature and wash cycles as well. [6] X Research source Make sure that the ink stain is fully removed before drying your jeans. Once the jeans are dry, leftover ink will be harder to remove. If the stain is still visible, repeat the entire one more time to remove the rest of the ink.

steps.title: Apply hand sanitizer to the ink stain as soon as you see it.
steps.content: Apply hand sanitizer to the ink stain as soon as you see it. Due to its high alcohol content, hand sanitizer is a great alternative to rubbing alcohol if you don’t have any on hand, and it’s also a good on-the-go option. Simply apply a small amount of hand sanitizer to the stain, and allow it to sit for a few minutes to break up the ink. Then, wash your jeans in the washing machine as usual, according to the instructions on the care label. [7] X Research source Be sure to perform a patch test on an inconspicuous area of the jeans first to make sure the hand sanitizer won’t affect the color of the fabric.

steps.title: Spray aerosol hairspray directly to the stain.
steps.content: Spray aerosol hairspray directly to the stain. Like hand sanitizer, aerosol hairspray tends to have a high alcohol content, which makes it effective at breaking down the oils in ink stains. Allow the product to sit for a few minutes, then wash your jeans in the washing machine as you normally would. [8] X Research source

steps.title: Spray the area with stain remover and allow it to soak.
steps.content: Spray the area with stain remover and allow it to soak. Shout and Oxiclean are great options, and they’re available at most grocery stores. Some commercial stain removers can be washed out right away, but others need to soak on the fabric for several minutes. Follow the instructions listed on the product you’re using. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Wash your jeans as normal in the washing machine.
steps.content: Wash your jeans as normal in the washing machine. After soaking the stain according to the product’s instructions, launder your jeans in the washing machine as you usually would. Be sure to follow the instructions on the care label when choosing the water temperature and washer cycle. [10] X Research source Check to make sure the stain is completely gone before drying. If the stain is still visible, repeat the process one more time.

steps.title: Mix equal parts white vinegar and cool water in a large bowl.
steps.content: Mix equal parts white vinegar and cool water in a large bowl. This mixture will serve as your all-natural stain remover. [11] X Research source You can make as much of the stain remover as you need, but for a small ink stain, about 1 ⁄ 2 cup (120 mL) vinegar and 1 ⁄ 2 cup (120 mL) water should be a good amount.

steps.title: Soak the stained area in the bowl.
steps.content: Soak the stained area in the bowl. Allow the ink stain to become fully saturated in the vinegar solution, and let it soak for about 30 minutes. You can also apply the solution directly to the stain instead of soaking it in the bowl, if you prefer. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Scrub the stain remover solution into the stain.
steps.content: Scrub the stain remover solution into the stain. After soaking, use a sponge or soft toothbrush to gently rub the stain in circular motions, until the ink is completely gone. [13] X Research source

steps.title: Wash your jeans in the washing machine.
steps.content: Wash your jeans in the washing machine. Check the care label on your jeans to choose the water temperature and wash cycle, and make sure the ink stain is completely gone before placing them in the dryer. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Mix equal parts baking soda and water, and apply it to the stain.
steps.content: Mix equal parts baking soda and water, and apply it to the stain. This creates an all-natural stain-removing paste that you can use for a wide variety of stains. Simply apply the mixture to the stained area, and let it sit for several minutes to break up the ink. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Scrub the area gently with a soft toothbrush, then rinse.
steps.content: Scrub the area gently with a soft toothbrush, then rinse. Make sure to use cool water when you rinse off the paste, as warm water can set the stain. If there’s still ink left over, add more paste to the stain, scrub it in, then rinse one more time. Repeat this process until the stain lifts completely. [16] X Research source When the stain is gone, wash your jeans in the washing machine as normal.

steps.title: Is it possible to remove an ink stain that has already dried?
steps.content: Is it possible to remove an ink stain that has already dried? Yes, it is possible to treat an ink stain after it has dried, but it will be a bit harder to remove. If you’re in this situation, allow the rubbing alcohol to soak for a full 15 minutes before blotting the area and rinsing it out. After rinsing out the alcohol, you may also want to apply a commercial stain remover like Shout or Oxiclean for some extra stain-fighting power. If you do this, allow the stain remover to soak for a while to break up and lift the ink, then wash your jeans into the washing machine as normal. [17] X Research source

steps.title: What is the difference between oil-based and water-based ink stains?
steps.content: What is the difference between oil-based and water-based ink stains? Washable markers and felt-tip pens tend to have water-based ink, while ballpoint pens usually have oil-based ink. Oil-based ink is tougher to remove than water-based ink, but the same stain removal methods work for both types. [18] X Research source If you're removing an oil-based ink stain, you may need to allow your stain remover of choice to soak for a bit longer to break up the ink. You may also need to repeat the process a few times to fully get rid of the stain.

steps.title: Does the rubbing alcohol stain removal method work for other fabrics?
steps.content: Does the rubbing alcohol stain removal method work for other fabrics? Yes, rubbing alcohol should work to remove ink stains from various fabric types, including cotton, linen, canvas, nylon, and polyester. [19] X Research source Regardless, always perform a patch test with rubbing alcohol before applying it to the stain, just to be safe. [20] X Research source This is especially important if you're treating a more delicate fabric, like silk or wool. If you notice that the fabric becomes slightly discolored after your patch test, try out a gentler stain removal option, like white vinegar or baking soda, instead.
